opinions.snippet:
The outstanding fact which must first be stated as underlying and conditioning every element involved in this controversy is as stated in the 1931 annual report of the Columbia Gas 
Electric Corporation, that all of the properties involved in this case are "thoroughly integrated and interconnected, they constitute a single operating unit."
With the exception of the qualifying shares, the Columbia Gas Electric Corporation, which is the parent corporation of this group, holds the entire

posture:
ERROR to the Public Utilities Commission.

These cases arise as proceedings in error to an order of the Public Utilities Commission, entered upon a complaint and appeal filed by the Columbus Gas  Fuel Company, protesting certain rates scheduled in an ordinance fixing the price to be charged for natural gas in the city of Columbus. This ordinance was submitted to a referendum vote at an election duly held, and approved by a majority of the qualified electors voting thereon. By its terms it provided for a rate of 48 cents per M c. f. with a minimum monthly charge of 75 cents, and was to become effective from and after November 12, 1929.

The petition in error filed in this court by the Columbus Gas Fuel Company in case No. 23864 reads in part as follows:

"Plaintiff in error says that it is a corporation organized under the laws of Ohio and engaged as a public utility in distributing natural gas for light, heat and power purposes to consumers in the city of Columbus, Franklin county, Ohio, and contiguous territory. That it is the owner of and operating and doing
business under a certain franchise granted by the city of Columbus to its predecessor in title, its successors and assigns, by Ordinance No. 4539, passed by the city council of the city of Columbus, Ohio, February 4, 1889.

"That on November 5, 1929, the city of Columbus passed an ordinance entitled 'An Ordinance, No. 645-29, to regulate the price that may be charged for natural gas in the city of Columbus during the period of five years from the twelfth day of November, 1929, and providing for the submission of this ordinance to a referendum vote at an election to be held November 5, 1929.'

"That said Ordinance No. 645-29 was submitted to a vote of the qualified electors of the city of Columbus and was approved by a majority of those voting thereon at the election held on November 5, 1929, and said ordinance by its terms became effective from and after November 12, 1929.

"That said Ordinance No. 645-29 was not accepted by plaintiff in error.

"Plaintiff in error further says that on the thirty-first day of December, 1929, it presented to and filed with the defendant in error, The Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, its complaint in writing that the rate and price so fixed to be charged for natural gas in the city of Columbus during the period of five years from said twelfth day of November, 1929, was and would be unlawful, unjust, unreasonable and insufficient to yield a reasonable compensation for the service, having due regard to the value thereof and of all the property of plaintiff in error actually used and useful for the convenience of the public in furnishing said service and to the necessity of making reservations from its income for surplus, depreciation, contingencies and such other matters as may be proper, including the purchasing of a supply of natural gas in order to furnish said service, and praying that after hearing and
investigation the commission determine the rate and price so fixed by said Ordinance No. 645-29 to be unlawful, unjust and unreasonable and insufficient to yield reasonable compensation for the service, and determine and fix the just and reasonable rate and price to be charged, demanded, exacted and collected therefor as required by law, and order the same submitted for the rate, charge and price fixed by said ordinance."

The majority of the commission entered an order setting aside the rates embodied in the ordinance and fixing the price to be charged for natural gas in the city of Columbus during the period in question at 55 cents per M c. f.

The commission found as follows with reference to the ordinance rate and with reference to the rate fixed in its order:

"That the rate per thousand cubic feet of 48¢, with an additional charge of 5¢ per thousand cubic feet, if the monthly bills are not paid within a fixed time, with a minimum charge of 75¢ per month without discount, fixed and prescribed by said Ordinance, are unreasonable and unjust and ought not to be ratified and confirmed, and that just and reasonable rates and charges should be substituted therefor;

"That the rate per thousand cubic feet of 55¢, with an additional charge of 5¢ per thousand cubic feet, if monthly bills are not paid within a fixed time, and a monthly minimum charge of 75¢, without discount, are just and reasonable rates and charges for the service furnished and supplied by said appellant in the City of Columbus, Ohio, and

"That the gross and net revenues derived by said The Columbus Gas and Fuel Company for furnishing natural gas for public and private consumption, in the City of Columbus, at the rates and charges hereinbefore found by the Commission to be just and reasonable will be sufficient to yield said The Columbus Gas
and Fuel Company a reasonable compensation for such service."

One member of the commission dissented from the holding of the majority of the commission, finding the rates charged in the ordinance in question to be reasonable, just and lawful, and sufficient to yield a reasonable compensation for the service under the statute.

Further facts are stated in the opinion.

(1) The will, by its terms, refers to and provides that it shall be construed under the laws of the State of Kansas. This reference and provision makes the law of Kansas as much a part of the will as though it had been inserted  verbatim  therein. Shulsky v. Shulsky,  98 Kan. 69 ; Chambers v. McDaniel, 28 N.C. 229 ; Vestry v. Bostwick, 8 App. B.C. 456; 40 Cyc. 1094, notes. (2) The trust sought to be created by the will is not a public charity, and is void on its face, under the laws of the State of Kansas, as being against the rule prohibiting perpetuities of title in estates, because the fund provided can only be used for the benefit of certain persons to be selected and certified by the "school board" from a classification of individuals, which does not arise in the course of nature, but is wholly arbitrary and grows out of and only exists in the "private conventions, class associations and artificial distinctions of men." Troutman v. DeBoissiere,  66 Kan. 1 . (3) The power to appoint and certify beneficiaries sought by said will to be conferred upon the
"school board" cannot be exercised. Its powers are fixed by statute and it cannot be the recipient of or exercise any power sought to be conferred upon it by an individual. Hence, the intended beneficiaries of the trust cannot be legally ascertained and determined. Harwood v. Tracy,  118 Mo. 637 ; Dodson v. Scruggs, 47 Mo. 285 ; Re Hoffer's Estate,  70 Wis. 407 ; Leman v. Sherman, 117 Ill. 657 ; Sinking Fund Commrs. v. Walker, 6 How. (U.S.) 143; Shaw v. Payne, 12 Allen (Mass.) 293; Dunbar v. Soule, 129 Mass. 284 ; McClary v. McLain,  2 Ohio St. 368 ; English v. Sailors' Snug Harbor, 3 Pet. (U.S.) 99; 1 Perry on Trusts, sec. 296; 35 Cyc. 899 et seq.; 39 Cyc. 272, and notes; 28 Am.  Eng. Ency. (2 Ed.) 965; 12 Am.  Eng. Ency. 301. (4) But even if such power of appointment could be conferred upon the "school board" the provisions of the will are incomplete and insufficient to permit action thereunder, because no standard or measure of the required qualifications of beneficiaries is provided, and no means or method is named by which the facts necessary to be certified may be ascertained. In re Hauck,  70 Mich. 410 ; Fountaine v. Ravenel, 19 How. (U.S.) 368; Beckman v. Bonsor,  23 N.Y. 298 ; Grimes v. Harman,  35 Ind. 220 ; Gallego's v. Atty. Gen., 3 Leigh, 450; Dashiel v. Atty. Gen., 5 Har.  Johns. 392; Hughes v. Daly, 49 Conn. 34 ; Lepage v. McNamara,  5 Iowa 124 ; White v. Fisk, 22 Conn. 31 . (5) The trust attempted to be created by the will cannot be sustained as a public charity because the State and the public, through its courts, possess no "admitted right of visitation and control." Troutman v. DeBoissiere,  66 Kan. 1 . On the contrary the will by its terms expressly precludes the courts from the exercise of such right and power.

 Dwight M. Smith  and  Goodwin Creason  for respondents.

(1) The attack upon the will in question being predicated upon the laws of Kansas, and no laws of
Kansas that affect the validity of the will being pleaded, the amended petition of plaintiff below stated no cause of action, and demurrer was properly sustained. Gibson v. Railroad, 225 Mo. 485 ; Rialto Co. v. Minor,  183 Mo. App. 128 ; McDonald v. Life Assn.,  154 Mo. 628 ; Lee v. Mo. Pac.,  195 Mo. 415 ; Coleman v. Lucksinger,  224 Mo. 14 ; Ginnochio v. Railroad,  155 Mo. App. 168 ; State v. Harty, 208 S.W. (Mo.) 837. (2) Since plaintiff's amended petition alleges the common law to be in force in Kansas, and pleads no statute or decision of Kansas modifying it, a Missouri court in construing the will in question must presume the common law of Kansas to be the same as the common law of Missouri, as found in its own decisions. McPike v. McPike,  111 Mo. 226 ; Kollock v. Emmert  Co.,  43 Mo. App. 570 ; Jordan v. Pence, 123 Mo. App. 324 ; Morrissey v. Wiggins Ferry Co.,  47 Mo. 525 ; Bank v. Com. Co.,  139 Mo. App. 124 . (3) The will in question, under the laws of Missouri, creates a public charity of the most unimpeachable character. Crow ex rel. v. Clay County, 196 Mo. 261 ; Catron v. Scarritt Collegiate Institute,  264 Mo. 725 ; Robinson v. Crutcher, 209 S.W. (Mo.) 104; Strother v. Barrow, 246 Mo. 241 ; Sandusky v. Sandusky,  261 Mo. 357 ; Hadley v. Forsee, 203 Mo. 426 ; Buchanan v. Kennard,  234 Mo. 139 ; Buckley v. Monck, 187 S.W. (Mo.) 34; Cummings v. Dent, 189 S.W. (Mo.) 1161; Sappington v. School Fund Trustees,  123 Mo. 32 ; Anderson v. Roberts, 147 Mo. 486 ; Lackland v. Walker,  151 Mo. 257 ; Chambers v. St. Louis, 29 Mo. 543 ; Howe v. Wilson,  91 Mo. 45 ; Powell v. Hatch,  100 Mo. 592 ; Barkley v. Donnelly,  112 Mo. 561 ; Missouri Hist. Society v. Academy of Science,  94 Mo. 466 . (4) The will is equally valid under Kansas statutes and decisions, as well as general law relating to charitable trusts. Troutman v. DeBoissiere, 66 Kan. 1 ; Washburn College v. O'Hara,  75 Kan. 700 ; Keeler v. Lauer, 73 Kan. 393 ; Secs. 9850, 9840, 9841, 7443, 7445, Statutes of Kansas 1909; 5 R.C.L. 309; 11 C.J. p. 361, sec. 20. (5) Since the will creates a valid public charity,
and provides competent trustees to take title, the heirs-at-law have no interest in the estate, and the plan provided in the will for designating beneficiaries does not concern them. W.C.A. v. Kansas City,  147 Mo. 103 ; Academy of Visitation v. Clemmens, 50 Mo. 167 ; Crow ex rel. v. Clay County,  196 Mo. 261 ; Sandusky v. Sandusky,  265 Mo. 234 ; Glaze v. Allen, 213 S.W. 785; Mott v. Morris,  249 Mo. 147 ; Barkley v. Donnelly,  112 Mo. 570 ; Harwood v. Tracy,  118 Mo. 631 ; 5 R.C.L. 299, 309, 370; 11 C.J. 342.
